Dear @CAPS1, I strongly believe that today's advances in technology and usage of computers are having a negative effect on people. Please let me further explain my thoughts... Firstly, people who spend too much time on their computers are proven to not get enough exercise! The average teenager will spend hars social networking with friends or people they don't even know, but will not spare half an hour to take a nice walk outside. "The human body," says fitness expert @PERSON1, "was not meant to stare at a glowing screen for hours at a time. Everyone, from every age group, needs to fit some physical activity in their daily routine to stay healthy." People who do not exercise their bodies could become dangerously obese, or could develop other problems such as heart disease. Clearly, computers are a mjaor contributor to the shrinking number of people who exercise every day. My second reason why i believe computers can be harmful is that people or the internet don't send enough time socializing with family or others. A survey by the @ORGANIZATION1 shows that one of the main reasons familities split up is because they don't spend any quality time with each other. If you don't even know the people you are closest to how can you develop social skills you'll need later in life? Negotiation skills, the ability to get along with fellow human beings, and basic compassion and etiquette are all abilities that must be cultivated out in the real world, because that is where they will be put to use. As you can see, it would be socially beneficial if we to limit our the on the computer. Finally, people who spend too much time on the internet are subjecting themselves to hidden dangers such as identity theft. Further, many adolescents, particularly females, who are victims of kidnapping or sexual assault say that they first met their attacher on the internet. Just a few seemingly benevalent convirsations can be enough for a predator to locate their next victim. It would seem evident that the internet, while having its benefits, harbors many dangers that become real as soon as you log on. In conclusion, i think the risks of over using a computer outweigh the benefits. My reasons are that users don't get enough exercise, people on the computer don't socialize with their fellow human beings, and that there are hidden dangers that nearly all computer users are subject to. I hope that we see eye to eye in this matter and that in the future, actions could be taken to present the previously described events from happening.

Dear @CAPS1, The "click-clock" of the keyboard as you type can be soothing. Whether somebody likes it or not, computers are needed for everyday life. Offices would be chaos without them; hospitals would loose patient info. and airports would be a disaster without them. But what about the average teenager or adult, using it for casual needs? Schools often have classes teaching students techniques on the computer. To complete homework, students have to use online textbooks, type of questions or essays, or use the internet for research for a project. Schools require children to use computers, so when they have that skill, why not use it? Computers teach people hand-eye coordination. Making the mouse without lookingat it and clicking on something on the screen can sometimes be a challenge for some. Typing too, without looking at the keyboard is challenging. with better hand-eye coordination, people have better motor skills for jobs in the near future. Better hand-eye coordination helps students in schools with basic sports in teams, or even in physical education, or @CAPS2.E. or gym. Having advanced hand-eye coordination is a bonus, as well as the skills on the computer. Since you are the @CAPS1 of a newspaper, think of how difficult it would be to paste together your newspaper without a computer or a computer software program that allows you to paste together a newspaper. When typing up articles, you could be hunched over, as some scientists puts it, and not "be enjoying nature." A lot of jobs require to use a computer for at least six hours per day. Although some kids have an unhealthy addiction to things on the computer, such as @CAPS3, @CAPS4, @CAPS5, etc. These addictions can be stopped by the action of a parent or a guardian. Children ,even adults, can be addicted to online video g ames such as world of warcraft. But, as i said before, those addictions can be easily taken care of by a parent or guardian. Can you imagine a world without the help of a computer? Without the advanced technology? It can seem pretty difficult, but for a modern society, time needs to be spent on the computer. Thank you for your time,

The Mooring Mast by @ORGANIZATION2 is about the tall and majestic Empire State Building and the efforts of putting New York on the forefront of modern travel. The Empire State Building had already become the world's tallest building in that time, but to make it better, Al Smith decided "he would add a top or hat to the building that would be even more distinctive than any other building in the city." The Empire State Building would serve as a transportation site where dirigible's would be able to let "passengers off and on".However, the architects of the Empire State Building faced obstacles in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. The idea shifted from theory to reality when people started seeing reasons "that should have been apparent before it was ever constructed." One of the reasons was the safety of a densely populated area such as downtown New York. The gases inside the dirigibles could catch on fire very quickly, therefore exploting and causing a catastrophe. In the case of the mooring mast itself was the wind. With violent air currents, the mast "would be dangling high above pedestrians on the street". Lastly, there was an existing law against "airships flying too low over urban areas".

Empire @CAPS1       In the excerpt "The Mooring Mast" by Marcia Amidon Lsted, the builders of the Empire State Building faced several @CAPS1 in attempting to allow dirigible to dock there. When faced with so many @CAPS1 expectations of the project began to fail. One of the @CAPS1 they faced was, that there wasn't enough landing area for the dirigible. In paragraph six of the excerpt it says, "the one obstacle to their expand use in New York City was the lack of a suitable landing area." Another obstacle they faced was, having to accommodate the dirigible's load and wind pressure when it was attached to the building by only one cable, because the arcitects couldn't simply drop a mooring mast on top of the Empire State Building's roof. In paragraph nine it says, "The steel frame of the Empire State Building would have to be modified and strengthened to accommodate this new situation." The last obstacle they faced was, the winds on top of the building were causing the dirigible to move. In the excerpt it says, "The winds on top of the building were constantly shifting due to violent air currents. Even if the dirigible were tethered to the mooring mast, the back of the ship would swivel around the mooring mast." As you can see, all of the @CAPS1 they faced when building the Empire State Building made it difficult for peoples expectations to be reached.

In the excerpt from "The Mooring Mast" by @ORGANIZATION2, the builders of the Empire State Building faced obstacles in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. The first problem appeared when the building was being constructed: how would the mass to be built? A dirigible moored on the building's flat roof would add an unmanageable amount of stress to the building's frame. Fixing this problem would cost over sixty thousand dollars. Second, docking dirigibles on the Empire State Building would be unsafe. The majority of foreign balloons used hydrogen, a highly flammable gas, over helium. If a hydrogen-filled balloon combusted "above a densely populated areas such as downtown New York," the damages would be catastrophic. A third obstacle that the builders faced was nature. The air currents above the Empire State Building would cause dirigibles to go around in circles. In this scenario, weighing down a dirigible with lead weights, "where they would be dangling high above pedestrians on the street," would not be safe. All three of the eight aforementioned obstacles posed problems for the builders of the Empire State Building in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there.

During the construction of the Empire State Building, builders faced several obstacles when attempting to allow the docking of dirigibles. Examples were the existing law against low flying airships in urban areas, safety concerns for the public and the fact of constant violent winds and air currents. One practical reason as to why dirigibles could not moor at the Empire @CAPS1 Building was because a law made it almost impossible for a ship to even approach the area, let alone tie up to a building. However, two ships made attempts before the idea was lost altogether. A very prominent obstacle was the safety concerns of the public. Dirigibles could be weighted down with lead in open fields, however having them hanging precariously above pedestrians was not practical or safe. The greatest obstacle was nature. Violent and dangerous winds constantly shifted, allowing even tethered dirigibles to swivel around the mooring mast. The obstacles in which workers faced proved to great for the dream of success. Laws, public safety concern and natural conditions had crushed the idea of a mooring dock by late 1930's.

Trying to build the tallest building and becoming the leaders in modern travel in the world was not easy for the people of New York City. The builders of the Empire State Building faced many obstacles when attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. For example, since there was no room in the building for the dirigibles to land, the builders knew that they had to build a mooring mast in order for dirigibles to anchor for refueling or service, and transporting people off and on. This is idea wasn't easy because it meant that a thousand-foot dirigible, which probably weighted a lot, had to be on top of the building held only by a single cable. Since the cable connected the building and the dirigibles, it meant that a lot of the stress of the dirigible's load would transmit all the way to the foundation of the building. The idea of building a dock for dirigibles was good for the time but it had several obstacles. The first was that the moored dirigible would add stress to the buildings frame. In The Mooring Mast by Marcia Amidon Lsted, the original plan for the Empire State building is revealed. Al Smith, the former governor that headed the project, wanted it to be the tallest building in the world, so he was going to add a mast. But as John Tauranac explained, this mast was meant to "serve a higher calling"-it was going to be equiped for use as a docking place for dirigibles. But the builders faced many obstacles in trying to accomplish this, some that they didn't even notice until after the building was completed. One of the many obstacles they faced was framework. Docking a dirigible to the top of the building would "add stress to the building's frame." This meant that the steel had to be "modified and strengthened." This is the only problem the architects were able to find, but in reality there were many more, such as safety. Blimps using hydrogen had the potential of catching on fire, which in turn would fall "above a densely populated area such as downtown New York." Also violent winds would make the back of the blimp "swing around the mooring mast." There was also the law against airships "flying too low over urban areas." All of these were potential hazards that would have stopped the building of the mast altogether, which the architects failed to notice. Clearly, the building of the mooring mast was not a well thought out plan. It was more competition and eageness to advance into the future. But safety and reality must always be aplied when chasing dreams, two things there were clearly not in Smith or the architects minds when designing the Empire State Building.

There were great expectations for the Empire State Building when it was originally built. However, like anything, many obstacles stood in their way. Perhaps the biggest was that of the mooring mast. Originally, the top was built so that "would allow dirigibles to anchor there for several hours for refueling service" (¦ 6). However, it was not meant to be. Winds at such a high altitude are dangerous. If people were to try to get off, shifting of the dirigibles could make it very difficult. Lead weights could be used to weigh it down, but having them dange over one-thousand feet above people was not appealing. The winds simply did not allow it. Winds were a major problem, but others arose as well. In @NUM1, the Hindenburg dirigible burnt to it's destruction while landing in Lakehurst, New Jersey. Many people had died. However, if this had happened above New York, falling debrise could have made it much worse. It was perhaps for this reason that a law forbidding airships from flying over cities too low was created. This made the mooring mast near-pointless. It was thus never fully used, and today the Empire State building is just a building with an observation tower with no dirigibles approaching.

Through attempting to mold the Empire State Building into a revolutionary port for dirigibles, the builders of the Empire State Building had to overcome major architectural challenges, such as constructing a sturdy building frame to support the mast, designing an efficient space for boarding passengers, and also to sculpt an elegant mast appealing to the eye of air travelers across the globe. The first obstacle to hurl over for the constructers of this project that was deemed to redefine the age of transportation was to find a way to build a skyscrapper that could support the weight and pull of a thousand-foot dirigible tied to the mast atop the building without hulling the building over. The engineers of this project, realizing that the pressure from the immense dirigible would be spanned out throughout the building, thus decided to make improvements to the building's steel frame itself to strengthen it for its new docking purpose. Another challenge builders had to face was to plot efficient space to accommodate all the needs of air travel, like areas for baggage, tickets, observation, and boarding. The builders swiftly conquered this work by building one-hundred-two floors equipped with elevators to bring people quickly to their luggage and an extra observation area to effectively double boarding space for passengers. The final artistic challenge for the architects of the Empire State Building was to not only build a mast, but build mast with style. Ready for the challenge, architects beautifully designed a mast in shiny aluminum that would be perched on a sleek stainless steel tower that would glow from within at night. Although the Empire State Building failed at it's desired purpose as a dirigible docking station, the builders of it try to make it a reality to the best of their abilities by solidifying the buildings frame, making comfortable areas for travelers, and carving into an elegant world structure.

The obstacles that the builders faced in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there were stuff like steel. The obstacles the builders of the empire state building faced in attempting to follow dirigibles to dock there; the greatest reason was one of safety: most dirigibles from outside of the united states use hydrogen rather than helium, and hydrogen is highly flammable. The winds on top of the building were constantly shifting due to violent air currents. The open landing fields could be weighed down in the back with lead weights, using these at the empire state building, where they would be dangling high above pedestrians on the street was neither practical or safe.

There were many obstacles facing the builders of the Empire State Building when attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. The first problem was that a dirigible would add more stress than the building's frame was intended for. To accommodate the unanticipated weight the frame of the building had to be strengthened, costing "over sixty thousand dollars." The second problem encountered was the wind. "The winds on top of the building were constantly shifting." The end of the dirigible that was unmoored would move resulting in safety issues. On dirigibles moored to the ground weights could be used to hold one end down. However this couldn't be done so high up. The final obstacles the builders were faced with was a law against airships flying to low above urban areas. This made it illegal to fly close enough to the Empire State Building to moor a dirigible. The largest obstacles the builders had to face when attempting to allow dirigibles to moor on the top of the Empire State building should've been a clue that the plan would fail.

The author decides to end the story ÒWinter HibiscusÓ this way to emphasize her main theme, and connect the events and emotions in a sentence so the reader can better relate to her story. The author establishes an ending that summarizes her story and connects it all, however, she still leaves it open for the reader to wonder what might happen and also to connect this to his or her own life. The tone that the author creates by this last sentence is of @CAPS1 and a way of adjusting to a new life. Throughout the story, the girl Saeng has been defined by nostalgia, her longing for the past. This is especially shown when the flowers she had once seen in Vietnam were in the florist shop: ÒSaeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral". She remembered finding the petals of this plant in her well. When describing SaengÕs nostalgia, the author had used imagery words to draw the reader in and almost becore Saeng. The end ties in this imagry of the hibiscus, only this five, it is a hibiscus blooming in a region where it struggles to grow as well as in Vietnam: Ò Its flowers arenÕt as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.Ó This is a symbol of Saeng adjusting to her new life. At the end, the images of the hibiscus blooming, and the geese returning after finding a way to adjust, make a deep meaning to what the author has built up: @CAPS1 for adjustment. Finally, the author puts Ò...then I will take the test again; meaning that Saeng will be ready and will adjust like the hibiscus and geese. Therefore, the author uses it to previous imagry together to emphasize her theme ad get reader to think about the situation in a deep way.

Ò'When then come back', saeng vowed silently to herself,'in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again'." The author ended the story with this paragraph because it sums up the point of the story. The beginning of the story was about her hibiscus and the test, the middle was about her failing and planting a new one with her mother, and the end paragraphs sums it all up. By her saying that she is willing to try again when the hibiscus is budding, it shows that she is adjusting to her new lifestyle and is confident in herself. Moving to a new country isnÕt easy, but Saeng overcame her fear and is willing to start over. Therefore, the ending paragraph is perfect, because it turns the negative story into a positive.

The author of the short story, ÒWinter Hibiscus,Ó Minfong Ho, concludes his piece with this paragraph to create a cliffhanger. A cliffhanger is a sudden ending in a story that allows the reader to create an ending for him/herself. The main character, Saeng, composes herself to this winter hibiscus in that ÒitÕs strong enough to make it through the cold months.Ó She is strong enough to make it through tough times such as moving from one country to another, and failing her driving test. ÒWhen the snows meltÉ and this hibiscus is budding, then [Saeng] will take that test again.Ó If the hibiscus can be reborn, then so can she. Narciso Rodriguez had many different moods in his memoir. He felt bad that his parents had to move to a new country to support him and leave all there friends and family. He felt happy that people from different cultures could get along in one community. He felt glad that his parents try to make his house the most like home as possible. These are three different moods he showed in his memoir.

The author decided to conclude the story with the paragraph given in order to give a powerful statement that wraps up the story well. In the paragraph, Saeng is explaining when she takes the driverÕs test again, everything in her life will be at a new, fresh start and she will be able to let go of the past. At the beginning of the story, it says that Saeng had failed her driverÕs test. Then, throughout the middle of the story, memories of SaengÕs past are revealed when she sees a familiar plant, making her sad. This shows that Saeng misses her old life, perhaps in her homeland, and is feeling out of place and lost in this new world. In the paragraph at the very end of the story, Saeng is vowing that when nature and the world around her takes a fresh start, so will she in this new life. She was saying that she will no longer be hung up on memories of the past but instead make new memories and be successful, thus having a new start. The author intentionally conveyed this message of SaengÕs future to the reader in order to tell them that Saeng will be able to move on, therefore giving a powerful, final statement that ends the story.

The mood then shifts to a unifying, or togetherness mood, "all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The mood change into a mood of sacrafice and hardship "my parents might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserve." @CAPS1 the mood is thankfulness, "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love".

In the memoir The Blueprints Of Our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez there is a mood portrayed troughout the whole memoir. And it is happyness, love, caring. For example the text states, "... We a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being blood relative... Our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants...all of those cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." (paragraph @NUM1). This quote shows that all of the people care for each other greatly. Another main statement is when the text states, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life even though it ment leaving behind their families, friends and careers in the country they loved" (paragraph @NUM2). This quote shows that parents are willing to give up anything if it means their child will be happy. Lastley, is happyness which the text states clearly, "It was here where I learned the real definition of "family" and for this I will never forget that house ... many things I learned to love" (paragraph @NUM3). This quote shows that you can learn to love anything. In short, the mood is happy troughout the whole memoir.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author was compassion. First, the author talked about his community and how they helped anybody in need.
